abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Prioritization is the process whereby a set of possible candidate genes or <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s is ranked so that the most promising can be taken forward into further studies. In a genome‐wide association study, prioritization is usually based on the <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content></jats:italic>‐values alone, but researchers sometimes take account of external annotation information about the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s such as whether the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> lies close to a good candidate gene. Using external information in this way is inherently subjective and is often not formalized, making the analysis difficult to reproduce. Building on previous work that has identified 14 important types of external information, we present an approximate <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">B</jats:styled-content>ayesian analysis that produces an estimate of the probability of association. The calculation combines four sources of information: the genome‐wide data, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> information derived from bioinformatics databases, empirical <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> weights, and the researchers’ subjective prior opinions. The calculation is fast enough that it can be applied to millions of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNPS</jats:styled-content> and although it does rely on subjective judgments, those judgments are made explicit so that the final <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> selection can be reproduced. We show that the resulting probability of association is intuitively more appealing than the <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content></jats:italic>‐value because it is easier to interpret and it makes allowance for the power of the study. We illustrate the use of the probability of association for <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> prioritization by applying it to a meta‐analysis of kidney function genome‐wide association studies and demonstrate that <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> selection performs better using the probability of association compared with <jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content></jats:italic>‐values alone.</jats:p>

reference.article-title: Importance of different types of prior knowledge in gene prioritization for follow‐up of genome‐wide findings
reference.author: Minelli C

title: <scp>SNP</scp> Prioritization Using a <scp>B</scp>ayesian Probability of Association
